title: rna_multisample
description: Processing unimodal multi-sample RNA transcriptomics data.

Dataset input.title: Dataset input
Dataset input.description: Dataset input using nf-tower "dataset" or "data explorer". Allows for the input of multiple         parameter sets to initialise a Nextflow channel.

param_list.description: Dataset input can either be a list of maps, a csv file, a json file, a yaml file, or simply a yaml                 blob. The names of the input fields (e.g. csv columns, json keys) need to be an exact match with the workflow input parameters.

id.description: Type: `string`, required, example: `concatenated`. ID of the concatenated file
id.help_text: Type: `string`, required, example: `concatenated`. ID of the concatenated file

input.description: Type: `file`, required, example: `dataset.h5mu`. Path to the samples
input.help_text: Type: `file`, required, example: `dataset.h5mu`. Path to the samples.

layer.help_text: Type: `string`. Input layer to use. If not specified, .X is used.

output.description: Type: `file`, required, default: `$id.$key.output.h5mu`, example: `output.h5mu`. Destination path to the output
output.help_text: Type: `file`, required, default: `$id.$key.output.h5mu`, example: `output.h5mu`. Destination path to the output.

highly_variable_features_var_output.help_text: Type: `string`, default: `filter_with_hvg`. In which .var slot to store a boolean array corresponding to the highly variable features.

highly_variable_features_obs_batch_key.description: Type: `string`, default: `sample_id`. If specified, highly-variable features are selected within each batch separately and merged
highly_variable_features_obs_batch_key.help_text:
Type: `string`, default: `sample_id`. If specified, highly-variable features are selected within each batch separately and merged. This simple 
process avoids the selection of batch-specific features and acts as a lightweight batch correction method. 
For all flavors, featues are first sorted by how many batches they are highly variable. For dispersion-based flavors 
ties are broken by normalized dispersion. If flavor = 'seurat_v3', ties are broken by the median (across
batches) rank based on within-batch normalized variance.

highly_variable_features_flavor.description: Type: `string`, default: `seurat`, choices: ``seurat`, `cell_ranger`, `seurat_v3``. Choose the flavor for identifying highly variable features
highly_variable_features_flavor.help_text:
Type: `string`, default: `seurat`, choices: ``seurat`, `cell_ranger`, `seurat_v3``. Choose the flavor for identifying highly variable features. For the dispersion based methods
in their default workflows, Seurat passes the cutoffs whereas Cell Ranger passes n_top_features.

highly_variable_features_n_top_features.description: Type: `integer`. Number of highly-variable features to keep
highly_variable_features_n_top_features.help_text: Type: `integer`. Number of highly-variable features to keep. Mandatory if filter_with_hvg_flavor is set to 'seurat_v3'.

var_qc_metrics.description: Type: List of `string`, default: `filter_with_hvg`, example: `ercc,highly_variable`, multiple_sep: `","`. Keys to select a boolean (containing only True or False) column from
var_qc_metrics.help_text:
Type: List of `string`, default: `filter_with_hvg`, example: `ercc,highly_variable`, multiple_sep: `","`. Keys to select a boolean (containing only True or False) column from .var.
For each cell, calculate the proportion of total values for genes which are labeled 'True', 
compared to the total sum of the values for all genes.

top_n_vars.description: Type: List of `integer`, default: `50,100,200,500`, multiple_sep: `","`. Number of top vars to be used to calculate cumulative proportions
top_n_vars.help_text:
Type: List of `integer`, default: `50,100,200,500`, multiple_sep: `","`. Number of top vars to be used to calculate cumulative proportions.
If not specified, proportions are not calculated. `--top_n_vars 20,50` finds
cumulative proportion to the 20th and 50th most expressed vars.

output_obs_num_nonzero_vars.description: Type: `string`, default: `num_nonzero_vars`. Name of column in
output_obs_num_nonzero_vars.help_text:
Type: `string`, default: `num_nonzero_vars`. Name of column in .obs describing, for each observation, the number of stored values
(including explicit zeroes). In other words, the name of the column that counts
for each row the number of columns that contain data.

output_obs_total_counts_vars.description: Type: `string`, default: `total_counts`. Name of the column for
output_obs_total_counts_vars.help_text:
Type: `string`, default: `total_counts`. Name of the column for .obs describing, for each observation (row),
the sum of the stored values in the columns.

output_var_num_nonzero_obs.description:
Type: `string`, default: `num_nonzero_obs`. Name of column describing, for each feature, the number of stored values
(including explicit zeroes)
output_var_num_nonzero_obs.help_text:
Type: `string`, default: `num_nonzero_obs`. Name of column describing, for each feature, the number of stored values
(including explicit zeroes). In other words, the name of the column that counts
for each column the number of rows that contain data.

output_var_total_counts_obs.description: Type: `string`, default: `total_counts`. Name of the column in
output_var_total_counts_obs.help_text:
Type: `string`, default: `total_counts`. Name of the column in .var describing, for each feature (column),
the sum of the stored values in the rows.

output_var_obs_mean.description: Type: `string`, default: `obs_mean`. Name of the column in
output_var_obs_mean.help_text: Type: `string`, default: `obs_mean`. Name of the column in .obs providing the mean of the values in each row.

output_var_pct_dropout.description: Type: `string`, default: `pct_dropout`. Name of the column in
output_var_pct_dropout.help_text:
Type: `string`, default: `pct_dropout`. Name of the column in .obs providing for each feature the percentage of
observations the feature does not appear on (i.e. is missing). Same as `--num_nonzero_obs`
but percentage based.

nextflow input-output arguments.title: Nextflow input-output arguments
nextflow input-output arguments.description: Input/output parameters for Nextflow itself. Please note that both publishDir and publish_dir are supported but at least one has to be configured.

publish_dir.description: Type: `string`, required, example: `output/`. Path to an output directory
publish_dir.help_text: Type: `string`, required, example: `output/`. Path to an output directory.
